text.p: Grain and oilseed exports reported by USDA and private export sources.
WHEAT SALE - Egypt bought 400,000 tonnes of soft red American wheat at $143.40 per tonne FOB for delivery in June and July, an Egyptian official said.
SOYMEAL SALE - A South Korean buyer group, known as the Big Feed Mills, bought 30,000 tonnes of Brazilian soymeal at $319.50 a tonne C&F, traders said. Shipment was for July 20-August 10.

BARLEY SALE - Iran on Tuesday bought 100,000 tonnes of optional-origin feed barley for August shipment, European grain traders said. One European trader pegged the average equivalent FOB export price at about $150 per tonne.

SOYBEAN TENDER - The Taichung division of Taiwan's Breakfast Soybean Procurement Association should tender Thursday for 54,000 tonnes of U.S., Brazilian or Argentine soybeans for July shipment, traders said.
WHEAT TENDER - The CCC seeks 13,500 tonnes of U.S. soft white wheat, maximum moisture 13.5 percent, for donation to Pakistan. Offers were to be submitted on May 22. Shipment was for June 10-July 15.
- Results were awaited on a Philippine flour miller tender to buy 7,500 tonnes of U.S. western white wheat, traders said. The wheat is for June shipment.
- Results are awaited on this week's Iraq's tender for 50,000 tonnes of U.S. hard red winter wheat for July shipment under a United Nations oil-for-food deal.
RICE TENDERS - Syria's General Foreign Trade Organisation for Chemicals and Foostuffs seeks offers June 4 to buy 12,000 tonnes of white rice for July with confirmation on June 12.
RICE TENDERS - The state-run Rice Export Corporation of Pakistan invited bids by May 26 for the export of 5,000 tonnes of basmati Pak-7 rice containing seven percent broken.
- Jordan seeks 15,000 tonnes of medium grain camolina type rice on May 21 for June delivery
MARKET TALK - Mexico's central Guanajuato state has pulled together 40 million pesos in finance to facilitate wheat purchases by millers for around 300,000 tonnes of grain, the state government said.

MARKET TALK - The U.S. Agriculture Department said Wednesday it released an additional $120 million in short-term GSM-102 export credits to Turkey to facilitate U.S. ag exports during fiscal 1997. With the release, $300 million in short-term credits has been offered to Turkey for fiscal 1997, which ends September 30. USDA said it did not alter the commodities eligible for the credits nor the terms for them.
